abstract.text: A description of a single attribute belonging to an entity.

inlineContent.text: , which provides most of the basic behavior. Instances of

are used to describe attributes, as distinct from relationships. The class adds the ability to specify the attribute type, and to specify a default value. In a managed object model, you must specify the type of all attributes—you can only use the undefined attribute type (

Attribute descriptions are editable until they are used by an object graph manager. This allows you to create or modify them dynamically. However, once a description is used (when the managed object model to which it belongs is associated with a persistent store coordinator), it

(indeed cannot) be changed. This is enforced at runtime: any attempt to mutate a model or any of its sub-objects after the model is associated with a persistent store coordinator causes an exception to be thrown. If you need to modify a model that is in use, create a copy, modify the copy, and then discard the objects with the old model.
Default values set for attributes are retained by a managed object model, not copied. This means that attribute values do not have to implement the
protocol, however it also means that you should not modify any objects after they have been set as default values.

abstract.text: Persist or cache data on a single device, or sync data to multiple devices with CloudKit.
A description of a single attribute belonging to an entity.
The types of attributes that Core Data supports.
A Boolean value that determines whether to encrypt the attribute’s value.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the attribute allows external binary storage.
The attribute’s type.
The class name that represents the attribute’s value.
The default value of the attribute.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the attribute records its value in the persistent history transaction for a managed object’s deletion.
The attribute’s type.
The name of the transformer to use for the attribute value.
The version hash for the attribute.
The types of attribute that Core Data supports.
A description of an attribute that derives its value by composing other attributes.
A description of an attribute that derives its value by performing a calculation on a related attribute.
A description of a single property belonging to an entity.
A description of a relationship between two entities.
Review unsupported symbols and their replacements.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
